articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Andrew Morton sent out more patches on Wednesday that have been pulled into the Linux 6.10 kernel. Notable from this latest round of "non-MM" updates is enabling more compiler warnings by default and getting newer AMD GPUs working on the RISC-V architecture...
articles.title: Newer AMD Radeon Graphics Cards Now Work On RISC-V With Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: GNOME Shell and Mutter had been covered by Ubuntu's GNOME MicroReleaseException "MRE" policy that allows for new point releases to ship rather easily as stable updates to existing Ubuntu Linux releases. But breaking the camel's back is GNOME 46.1 shipping explicit sync support. Due to landing a "significant new feature" into a point release, the GNOME Shell and Mutter are no longer covered by this exception...
articles.title: GNOME Shell & Mutter Broke Their Good Faith With Ubuntu

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: All of the VirtIO updates are now ready for the Linux 6.10 merge window that is closing this weekend...
articles.title: VirtIO Improvements Ready For Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: It looks like systemd 256 will officially debut as stable in the near future with systemd 256-rc3 being released today and not tacking on any new features compared to the prior release candidates...
articles.title: systemd 256 Nears Release With run0, systemd-vpick, importctl & More

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Greg Kroah-Hartman today sent in the char/misc updates for Linux 6.10 alongside the other areas of the kernel he oversees. Among the char/misc changes is adding the NTSYNC driver that exposes the /dev/ntsync character device for use by the likes of Wine and Valve's Steam Play (Proton). But for Linux 6.10 the driver is effectively "broken" as most of the feature patches have yet to be included...
articles.title: Initial Windows NT Sync Driver Merged Into Linux 6.10 But Not Yet Complete

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Eric Engestrom has announced the release of Mesa 24.1 as this quarter's feature release to these open-source OpenGL and Vulkan drivers...
articles.title: Mesa 24.1 Released With Explicit Sync Vulkan Drivers, More Mature NVK Driver

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The latest RISC-V port updates have been merged for the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel...
articles.title: RISC-V Now Supports Rust In The Linux Kernel

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Back in February 2022 prior to the Valve Steam Deck being released, a Steam Deck Platform Driver was posted for the Linux kernel. Sadly, more than two years later, this driver still hasn't been upstreamed into the mainline Linux kernel and it looks like it could still be months before it happens...
articles.title: Steam Deck Platform Driver In No Apparent Rush For Upstreaming Into The Linux Kernel

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Introduced last year with the Linux 6.7 kernel was a hardening configuration to allow for "make hardening.config" as an easy way of building a security-hardened Linux kernel with sane defaults. With Linux 6.10 there are some additional security minded features now enabled...
articles.title: Linux 6.10's Hardening Configuration Now Enables KCFI & Other Features

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Greg Kroah-Hartman sent out the USB/Thunderbolt changes this morning for the Linux 6.10 merge window that is wrapping up this weekend. Surprisingly, in 2024, a new USB to parallel printer port adapter variant is being introduced with Linux 6.10...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Shows People Are Still Using USB To Parallel Port Adapters In 2024

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The FUSE updates have been submitted for the Linux 6.10 kernel in supporting file-system implementations within user-space...
articles.title: FUSE Adds VirtIO-FS Multi-Queue For ~5x Performance Win With Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Alpine Linux 3.20 has been released as the newest feature release to this security-minded, lightweight Linux distribution that is popular for embedded and container use. Alpine Linux continues to set itself apart from others by making use of musl libc, Busybox, and other modifications in the name of security and small footprint...
articles.title: Alpine Linux 3.20 Released With Initial 64-bit RISC-V Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Sent out on Tuesday were all of the perf tool changes for the Linux 6.10 kernel. This includes perf event support for recent Intel CPUs as well as initial AMD Zen 5 processor support...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Perf Tools Brings AMD Zen 5 Events & Intel Updates

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The KVM changes for the Linux 6.10 kernel were merged a few days ago for this important piece to the open-source Linux virtualization stack...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 KVM Does More Prepping For Intel TDX

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Eclipse OpenJ9 v0.45 is now available as the newest version of this high performance JVM for Java applications...
articles.title: Eclipse OpenJ9 v0.45 Released For Supporting OpenJDK 22

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Last week the main SoC/platform updates were sent in for Linux 6.10 that included more ARM-based handheld game consoles and other new Arm devices from ASUS wireless routers to set-top boxes to enabling various SoCs. This week a secondary set of updates were submitted for the Linux 6.10 kernel merge window...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Adds Support For The RISC-V Milk-V Mars & More SoC Additions

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Box64 is out as the newest version of this Linux user-space x86_64 emulator for running on ARM64 Linux devices. There is also an updated version of Box86 too for that x86 32-bit version on ARM...
articles.title: Box64 0.2.8 Released With Support For 16K Page Size - Allowing Games On Apple Silicon

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: As a follow-up to this morning's AMD EPYC 4004 review and benchmarks, Supermicro, ASRock Rack, Giga Computing, Tyan, and others have announced new motherboards/servers for these entry-level EPYC servers. In addition with the likes of ASRock Rack they have already published BIOS updates enabling existing AM5 Ryzen server boards to officially support the EPYC 4004 series processors...
articles.title: ASRock Rack Releases BIOS Update For EPYC 4004 Support With AM5 Ryzen Boards

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: It's coming a week later than anticipated but the NVIDIA R555 Linux driver beta has been released! This is the NVIDIA proprietary Linux driver update that brings Wayland explicit sync support along with a host of other important improvements...
articles.title: NVIDIA 555.42.02 Linux Beta Brings Wayland Explicit Sync, GSP Firmware Used By Default

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Over the past several years we have seen AMD Ryzen processors being used for low-cost servers, budget web hosting platforms, game servers, and more. Since the Ryzen 5000 series we have seen the likes of ASRock Rack and Supermicro putting out interesting budget-friendly Ryzen servers and that has ramped up even more with AMD Ryzen 7000 series server performance being stellar thanks to AVX-512 and other improvements making it more practical for such workloads. AMD has now solidified its positioning for entry-level servers with the introduction of the EPYC 4004 series processors. The EPYC 4004 series is derived from the Ryzen 7000 series offerings to facilitate cost conscious server options and putting the Intel Xeon E-2400 series in the crosshairs. In this review is a look at the EPYC 4004 series along with benchmarks of nearly the entire EPYC 4004 product stack compared to Intel's current top-end Xeon E-2400 series processor, the Intel Xeon E-2488 Raptor Lake.
articles.title: AMD EPYC 4004 Benchmarks: Outperforming Intel Xeon E-2400 With Performance, Efficiency & Value

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Ahead of the planned release in August, the first alpha release of the LibreOffice 24.8 open-source office suite is now available for testing...
articles.title: LibreOffice 24.8 Alpha 1 Open-Source Office Suite Released

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Qualcomm and their partners at Linaro have been busy working on the Linux support for the Snapdragon X Elite as the high-end Arm SoC beginning to roll-out for laptops. The latest Snapdragon X Elite upstreaming is Embedded DisplayPort and DisplayPort support for the Snapdragon X Elite...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Adds eDP/DisplayPort Support For The Snapdragon X Elite

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: There's a lot of file-system activity going on for the Linux 6.10 merge window: Bcachefs safety improvements, better OCFS2 write performance, continued XFS online repair, and even a "mail-in merge request" from prison for ReiserFS. The Flash-Friendly File-System (F2FS) has also seen some new feature work this cycle and has now been merged...
articles.title: F2FS With Linux 6.10 Delivers Better Performance On Zoned Storage

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: André Zwing continues hacking on the Hangover project as a means of running Windows applications on AArch64 Linux by leveraging Wine and pairing it with emulators like QEMU, FEX, or Box64. Besides the initial AArch64/ARM64 focus, Hangover can be important for bring Windows game/application on Linux support eventually to other architectures like POWER and RISC-V...
articles.title: Hangover 9.9 Adds Support For Using The NTSYNC Driver

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While GCC 14 recently debuted as stable in the form of GCC 14.1, for those relying on the GCC 13 compiler that debuted last year there is now a new point release available with many bug fixes...
articles.title: GCC 13.3 Compiler Released With Tons Of Bug Fixes

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: In addition to the CXL updates for Linux 6.10 that were sent in last week, the PCI subsystem updates this week bring a notable addition for Compute Express Link (CXL) devices...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Adds Support To Reset CXL Devices

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Qt Company today released Qt 6.7.1 as the first point release for the cross-platform Qt 6.7.1 toolkit. Since releasing Qt 6.7 just under two months ago, they have fixed more than 400 bugs...
articles.title: Qt 6.7.1 Released With 400+ Fixes - Including Several Wayland Fixes

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The XFS file-system improvements have been merged for the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel...
articles.title: XFS Expanding Its Online Repair Capabilities In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While ReiserFS is obsolete and will eventually be dropped from the upstream Linux kernel in Linux 6.10 is one last ReiserFS change that was requested by former lead developer Hans Reiser...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Honors One Last ReiserFS Request Made By Hans Reiser

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Red Hat engineers have been developing Nova as a new, Rust-written open-source NVIDIA kernel graphics driver as the eventual successor to the Nouveau kernel driver and is designed around NVIDIA's GPU System Processor (GSP) thus making the driver relevant for RTX 20 / Turing GPUs and newer. Today they posted a request for comments (RFC) patch series of the Nova driver and Rust DRM abstractions...
articles.title: RFC Patches Posted For Rust-Written NVIDIA "Nova" GPU Driver

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel previously indicated that Lunar Lake processors would launch by the end of 2024 and leading to anticipation of a Q4 launch... Intel today announced that Lunar Lake will actually launch in Q3...
articles.title: Intel Announces Q3'2024 Arrival For Lunar Lake

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The x86 platform driver updates have been merged for the ongoing Linux 6.10 merge window. The platform-drivers-x86 changes continue to primarily revolve around x86 Intel/AMD laptops but also some other desktop/platform drivers. Now in Linux 6.10 there is also a new "ARM64" sub-section of the platform drivers...
articles.title: Many x86 Laptop Improvements In Linux 6.10 Plus Acer ARM Laptop

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Fedora Engineering and Steering Committee (FESCo) has approved of the newest Fedora desktop ISO spin: Fedora Miracle...
articles.title: Fedora Miracle Spin Approved To Ship As Part Of Fedora Linux 41

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Last week I wrote about Intel aiming to remove Xeon Phi support in GCC 15 with the products being end-of-life and deprecated in GCC 14. While some openly wondered whether the open-source community would allow it given the Xeon Phi accelerators were available to buy just a few years ago and at some very low prices going back years so some potentially finding use still out of them especially during this AI boom (and still readily available to buy used for around ~$50 USD), today the Intel Xeon Phi support was indeed removed...
articles.title: Farewell Intel Xeon Phi: Support Removed In The GCC 15 Compiler

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: It was just earlier this month that AMD Linux kernel graphics driver patches appeared for introducing a new ISP hardware block for Image Signal Processing with new AMD APUs. Already the AMDGPU ISP firmware has appeared in linux-firmware.git indicating that this "ISP" block may be coming in hardware quite soon if not already quietly found within some products...
articles.title: AMDGPU ISP Firmware Upstreamed In linux-firmware.git

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: It's not often having anything to write about on the Oracle Cluster File-System v2 (OCFS2), but with Linux 6.10 it's seeing a rather significant performance optimization...
articles.title: OCFS2 File-System Seeing Improved Write Performance On Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: As a small information heads up, the Linux 6.10 kernel will print the number of populated memory slots at boot time to the kernel log as a little helper...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Will Print The Number Of Populated Memory Slots At Boot Time

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel Compute Runtime 24.17.29377.6 is now available as the latest routine update to this open-source GPU compute stack used by the company's integrated and discrete graphics products for providing OpenCL and oneAPI Level Zero compute capabilities...
articles.title: Intel CR 24.17.29377.6 Offers Latest OpenCL & oneAPI Level Zero Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While Fwupd developers are working toward the Fwupd 2.0 release, out this morning is Fwupd 1.9.20 as the newest point release for this open-source solution for firmware updating on Linux that pairs with the Linux Vendor Firmware Service (LVFS)...
articles.title: Fwupd 1.9.20 Released With Updated FPC Fingerprint Reader Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Bcachefs lead developer Kent Overstreet today sent out his feature pull request of all the new file-system code that is ready in time for the Linux 6.10 merge window...
articles.title: Bcachefs Brings Safety Improvements To Linux 6.10, Preps For Online Fsck

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Released over a year ago was Golang 1.20 with support for Profile Guided Optimizations (PGO) and has since been improved with Go 1.21 for 2~7% faster Go binaries thanks to this optimization approach also found with other compilers. The engineers at Cloudflare have put out a blog post this week praising Go's PGO support and the CPU savings they are seeing as a result...
articles.title: Cloudflare Praises Golang PGO For Significant CPU Savings

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While EROFS is seeing Zstd support and Bcachefs is seeing performance optimizations with the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel, over on the mature EXT4 file-system side the changes are mostly small. There are some minor changes, more folio conversion work, and also adding support for the FS_IOC_GETFSSYSFSPATH ioctl that has been seeing some standardization and adoption by the common Linux file-systems...
articles.title: EXT4 In Linux 6.10 Adds FS_IOC_GETFSSYSFSPATH Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: A Linux patch has been posted for delivering a quirk so that the Bigscreen Beyond VR Headset can properly behave under Linux and in turn also jives with the likes of SteamVR...
articles.title: Linux Patch Posted For The Bigscreen Beyond VR Headset

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Alongside all of the other pull requests by Ingo Molnar submitted at the start of the week during the opening of the Linux 6.10 merge window were the scheduler updates. As usual, the kernel scheduler work continues to see various tweaks and refinements to enhance its behavior...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Scheduler Changes Bring More Refinements

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Linux's Turbostat utility that is developed by Intel for reporting idle/power state statistics, temperatures, and other useful data on modern Intel/AMD processors has seen its changes submitted for the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel...
articles.title: Turbostat Gains New Features & New Hardware Support With Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: SUSE/openSUSE has been busy crafting a next-gen Linux installer that is a web-based installer and originally known as D-Installer but now going by the name Agama...
articles.title: SUSE's YaST Team Drops Cockpit With New Installer Code

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Linux Network File System (NFS) server code (NFSD) is seeing a new Netlink protocol introduced in Linux 6.10 as part of laying the groundwork for the new "nfsdctl" utility...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 NFSD Brings Optimizations & Preps For New nfsdctl Utility

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Niri is a scrollable-tiling Wayland compositor inspired by PaperWM and heavy on the animations/effects. Out this morning is Niri 0.1.6 as the newest feature release for this Wayland compositor...
articles.title: Niri 0.1.6 Wayland Compositor Adds Interactive Window Resizing & Mouse View Scrolling

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund continues providing the resources for various new GNOME desktop development initiatives. There are various efforts underway for new features and refinements with GNOME 47 in September and a renewed emphasis around GNOME OS...
articles.title: GNOME OS Working On A New Installer & Other Enhancements To Make It More Practical

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The performance events updates were submitted today for the ongoing Linux 6.10 kernel merge window. This pull adds support for Advanced Performance Extensions (APX) and other new Intel CPU instructions to the x86 instruction decoder...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 x86 Instruction Decoder Prepares For APX & Other New Intel Instructions

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While machine check exception (MCE) events tend to be uncommon, a change made by Intel engineers is accommodating the ability in the Linux kernel to store more machine check records for "when things go seriously wrong" on increasingly high core count servers...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Preps For "When Things Go Seriously Wrong" On Bigger Servers

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: KDE development remains very busy ahead of next month's Plasma 6.1 desktop release...
articles.title: KDE Apps Improving Experience When Running Outside Of Plasma

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Wine 9.9 is out as the newest bi-weekly development release for running Windows games/applications on Linux and other platforms...
articles.title: Wine 9.9 Brings ARM Improvements, Drops Obsolete WineD3D Features

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Merged as part of the IRQ changes for the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel is support for posted interrupts on bare metal hardware...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Adds Support For Posted Interrupts On Bare Metal Hardware

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Oliver Smith who is serving as the Interim Engineering Director for the Ubuntu Desktop team at Canonical has shared some roadmap plans around Ubuntu 24.10. With this being the first post-LTS release following last month's Ubuntu 24.04 Long Term Support, they are more free to innovate this cycle and they have a lot of great plans for enhancing the Linux desktop experience...
articles.title: Ubuntu 24.10 To See More Polishing, NVIDIA Wayland By Default & New Welcome Wizard

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: OpenSUSE is the first major Linux distribution to package up and offer Intel's OpenVINO open-source AI toolkit within its package repository...
articles.title: Intel's OpenVINO Now Available In openSUSE

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: FSCRYPT is the file-system encryption framework within the Linux kernel for supporting optional encryption  on file-systems like EXT4, F2FS, and others. With Linux 6.10 an optimization is coming for enhancing the performance of opening files on file-systems supporting FSCRYPT-based encryption but when the files are unencrypted...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Improves Performance For Opening Unencrypted Files

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Compute Express Link (CXL) subsystem development continues to be led by Intel engineers and with the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel there are yet more features in tow...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Wires Up More Compute Express Link "CXL" Functionality

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: For the GCC 14 compiler release is the deprecation of the Xeon Phi targets. With Intel Knights Landing and Knights Mill being end-of-life at Intel, they are working to do away with the GNU Compiler Collection support. A patch has been posted to drop the Xeon Phi ISAs with GCC 15...
articles.title: Intel Readies Xeon Phi Removal For GCC 15

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The EROFS and Btrfs file-systems saw their feature patches merged as part of the ongoing Linux 6.10 merge window...
articles.title: EROFS Adds Zstd & Btrfs Gets Minor Performance Work In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The year-long effort to removal the sysctl sentinel for clearing bloat from the kernel and allowing faster build times should be crossing the finish line in Linux 6.10...
articles.title: Sysctl Sentinel Bloat Removal Wrapping Up In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The GNOME project has now solidified their release schedule for the current GNOME 47 development cycle: GNOME 47.0 should be out on 18 September...
articles.title: GNOME 47 Aims For Release On 18 September

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: This week AMD announced the Ryzen 5 8400F and Ryzen 7 8700F processors as new Zen 4 budget CPU contenders lacking any integrated graphics. While part of the Ryzen 8000 series, the 8400F also lacks the Ryzen AI support found in the higher-end SKUs. The Ryzen 5 8400F offers 6 cores / 12 threads, a 4.2GHz base clock and 4.7GHz boost clock, and a 65 Watt TDP while retailing for $169~189 USD. Here are some initial benchmarks of the AMD Ryzen 5 8400F in putting it up against 230+ benchmarks under Linux while also monitoring the CPU power consumption and comparing it to Intel's closest contender as the Core i5 1440F that retails for just under $200.
articles.title: AMD Ryzen 5 8400F vs. Intel Core i5 14400F: 230+ Benchmarks For Sub-$200 CPU Performance

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Following Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund providing significant funding for GNOME, Rust Coreutils, PHP, a systemd bug bounty, and numerous other free software projects, the FFmpeg multimedia library is the latest beneficiary to this funding from the Germany government...
articles.title: Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund Now Supporting FFmpeg

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: A patch has been posted by Samsung engineers for implementing Flexible Data Placement (FDP) support within the Linux kernel's NVMe driver code. NVMe FDP allows for the host system to have more control over the placement of logical blocks on the storage device...
articles.title: Linux Patch Posted For NVMe Flexible Data Placement (FDP)

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: As more positive indications around AMD's OpenSIL effort for open-source CPU silicon initialization to eventually replace AGESA, both AMD and Supermicro are now collaborating with the Open-Source Firmware Foundation. Supermicro has also publicly shown off a platform with OpenSIL+Coreboot and is said to be exploring OpenBMC for future hardware...
articles.title: AMD & Supermicro Collaborating On Open-Source Firmware With The OSFF

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Ampere Computing today made public their roadmap update concerning current and future AArch64 server processors. AmpereOne availability remains tough but the company is hoping next year to introduce a 3nm CPU with up to 256 cores and supporting 12 channel DDR5 memory.
articles.title: Ampere Computing 2024 Roadmap Update: 256 Core 3nm CPU In 2025

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Following last year's release of PipeWire 1.0 for managing audio and video streams on the Linux desktop and proving itself a capable replacement to PulseAudio and JACK, among other uses, PipeWire 1.2 is nearing release. Out today is the first release candidate of the upcoming PipeWire 1.2...
articles.title: PipeWire 1.2 Preps For Async Processing, Snap Support & Explicit Sync

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Coming as a surprise, longtime Linux developer Oded Gabbay announced he's left Intel / Habana Labs and is therefore stepping down from the maintainer role of the Linux kernel drivers for the Intel Xe DRM driver and more notably the Habana Labs accelerator driver that he's maintained from the start...
articles.title: Intel Habana Labs & Xe Linux Driver Maintainer Steps Down

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The open-source Mesa driver developers employed by Valve for working on the Linux graphics stack have begun preparing the RADV Vulkan driver and the ACO compiler back-end for the upcoming "GFX12" graphics IP for next-generation RDNA4...
articles.title: Valve's Linux Graphics Engineers Begin Prepping RADV Driver For AMD RDNA4 "GFX12"

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel's Image Processing Unit (IPU) IP has been a cause for concern in recent years as the lack of proper upstream open-source driver support has led Linux users running into troubles making use of MIPI camera sensors on modern laptops. Finally with Linux 6.10 the Intel IPU6 driver is being upstreamed into the media subsystem...
articles.title: Intel IPU6 Driver Being Upstreamed In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While most of you have not thought about or used Firewire (IEEE-1394) in years, there still are some legacy digital video cameras and some professional audio devices relying on the interface. Last year saw a new Firewire maintainer step-up for the Linux kernel after the code had fallen dormant. The plans by that new maintainer, Takashi Sakamoto, are to maintain Linux's Firewire support through 2029. He's continuing to do a good job with the upcoming Linux 6.10 kernel bringing the latest batch of Firewire enhancements...
articles.title: Firewire IEEE-1394 Support Continues To Be Improved With The Linux 6.10 Kernel

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Besides Linus Torvalds examining various elements of code he's merging and build testing it on his AMD Ryzen Threadripper workstation and now also testing more on ARM64 with Ampere Altra, he does these days still believe in "dogfooding" and is in fact running the leading-edge Linux kernel code even during the merge window...
articles.title: Linus Torvalds On Dogfooding The Linux Kernel

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Mesa 24.1 stable release is nearing while out today is the fourth weekly release candidate. While the Intel and AMD Radeon graphics driver changes typically dominate new Mesa releases, Mesa 24.1-rc4 is headlined by a big change for the NVK open-source NVIDIA Vulkan driver...
articles.title: Mesa 24.1-rc4 Backports NVK DRM Format Modifiers Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: One of the capabilities of newer Intel Xeon Scalable processors is support for Trust Domain Extensions (TDX) as a way of providing for confidential virtual machines. Intel TDX allows for "isolation, confidentiality, and integrity at the VM level" which is good from the security perspective but the dependence on signed binaries is causing mixed feelings within the Fedora camp at the broader open-source community...
articles.title: Intel TDX For Confidential VMs Causing Concern Among Fedora & Open-Source Advocates

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While Linux 6.10 is poised to merge the initial NTSYNC driver for a Windows NT Synchronization Primitive driver that can help with faster Windows gaming performance under Wine/Proton (Steam Play), the driver isn't complete. The initial patches have been in Greg Kroah-Hartman's char-misc-next branch for several weeks to expose the NTSYNC character device, it isn't the entire patch series. Greg has now marked the driver as "broken" for Linux 6.10...
articles.title: The NTSYNC Driver For Wine/Proton Is "Broken" For Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Back in February I wrote about AMD having quietly funded the effort for a drop-in CUDA implementation for AMD GPUs built atop the ROCm library. This was an incarnation of ZLUDA that originally began as a CUDA implementation for Intel GPUs using oneAPI Level Zero. While AMD discontinued funding ZLUDA development earlier this year, this CUDA implementation for AMD GPUs is continuing to see some new code activity...
articles.title: ZLUDA Has Been Seeing New Activity For CUDA On AMD GPUs

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Red Hat's Olivier Fourdan just announced the stable release of XWayland 24.1 as the newest feature release for this X.Org Server code allowing X11 clients to work within the confines of Wayland compositors...
articles.title: XWayland 24.1 Released With Explicit Sync, Better Rootful Experience

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The networking subsystem updates have been submitted for the Linux 6.10 kernel. As usual it's a big update with some 90,083 new lines of code and 37,889 lines removed...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Networking Adds New Intel Hardware Support, More WiFi 7 Enablement

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: It's been the better part of two months since the last AMDVLK driver update while today the AMDVLK 2024.Q2.1 driver has been christened...
articles.title: AMDVLK 2024.Q2.1 Driver Adds Phoenix 2 APU Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The big batch of Direct Rendering Manager (DRM) kernel graphics/display driver updates for the Linux 6.10 merge window were sent out today that includes the new "Panthor" driver for newer ARM Mali/Immortalis graphics processors and the usual hearty assortment of Intel and AMD graphics driver changes...
articles.title: Arm Mali/Immortalis GPU Driver, New AMD Graphics IP & Lunar Lake Display In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: https://github.com/canonical/mirCanonical engineer Matthew Kosarek just released Mir 2.17 as the newest version of this open-source Wayland compositor that can be used for building Wayland-based shells and has shown some interesting potential with the likes of Miracle-WM and Miriway...
articles.title: Mir 2.17 Better Supports Hybrid Graphics & Other Wayland Enhancements

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Along with the various Intel Xe2 driver changes that are ongoing for the Intel Linux graphics driver stack, over in the sound subsystem the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel is bringing HDMI audio support for upcoming Intel Battlemage graphics cards...
articles.title: Sound Support For Intel Battlemage In Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Linux kernel and Git creator Linus Torvalds is known for his current use of an AMD Ryzen Threadripper workstation as his main system after years of using Intel hardware. The past few years he's also been doing more ARM64 testing now that he has an Apple MacBook using Apple Silicon that serves as a nice travel device and for routinely compiling new ARM64 Linux kernel builds. More recently, his ARM64 Linux testing has increased now that he has a more powerful AArch64 system to complement his collection of routine gear...
articles.title: Linus Torvalds Is Doing More ARM64 Linux Testing Now That He Has A More Powerful System

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The first release candidate of systemd 256 came just under one month ago with new features like run0 as the new sudo alternative, a new "systemd-vpick" binary, importctl as another new tool, Zboot kernel support with systemd ukify, systemd-homed improvements, and much more. Systemd 256-rc2 is out this evening with a few more features and other fixes collected over the past several weeks...
articles.title: systemd 256-rc2 Released With A Few More Features

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Framework Laptops are some great systems with their upgradeable/modular design, friendly Linux support, both Intel and AMD options, the latest models making use of an open-source embedded controller, and nice build quality. The Framework Laptops have proven very popular with Linux/open-source enthusiasts but one of the recurring critiques has been the lack of Coreboot firmware support for these laptops as an alternative (or outright replacement) to the proprietary BIOS/firmware. As a promising avenue for the future, there is experimental work being done on getting Coreboot up and running with the Framework 13 laptop powered by the AMD Ryzen 7040 series...
articles.title: Framework 13 AMD Laptop Seeing Experimental Coreboot Port

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel just published a new set of CPU microcode files for updating Alder lake and newer as well as Xeon Scalable 4th Gen and 5th Gen in order to address three security issues plus take care of various functional issues...
articles.title: Intel Releases Updated CPU Microcode For Fixing Three New Security Issues

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Scaleway by way of their Scaleway Labs group recently launched the Elastic Metal RV1 (EM-RV1) as the world's first RISC-V servers available in the cloud. These RISC-V cloud servers are built around the T-Head 1520 SoC and are an interesting way to explore the RISC-V architecture and/or otherwise make use of RISC-V for CI/CD deployments or other testing purposes. In this article are some benchmarks showing the RISC-V EM-RV1 performance against Intel and AMD x86_64 Linux.
articles.title: Benchmarking The First RISC-V Cloud Server: Scaleway EM-RV1 Performance

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Back in late 2023 were Rust abstractions for the Linux kernel's Virtual File-System (VFS) code. Those patches by Microsoft engineer Wedson Almeida Filho have now seen a second iteration posted... In addition to various improvements to the Rust VFS bindings, the new patches bring a work-in-progress EXT2 Rust file-system driver...
articles.title: Microsoft Engineer Ports EXT2 File-System Driver To Rust

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Debian's APT packaging tool is working its way toward the big APT 3.0 release. The APT 2.9 development series is underway and debuting last month was APT's new (CLI) user interface with a columnar display, colored text, and other improvements for this widely-used tool on Debian-based environments. APT 2.9.3 is out today as the newest development release and new to this version is a new package solver...
articles.title: Debian Releases APT 2.9.3 With New Package Solver

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Human Interface Devices (HID) subsystem updates have been submitted for the newly-opened Linux 6.10 kernel merge window. Among the HID driver updates coming with Linux 6.10 are supporting the Steam Deck IMU motion sensors as well as HID coverage for the ASUS ROG Ally and ASUS ROG Z13 devices...
articles.title: Steam Deck IMU Support Submitted For Linux 6.10 Plus ASUS ROG Ally HID

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: After the 22 patches were under review for the past eight months, merged today is the NVK Vulkan driver support for the VK_EXT_image_drm_format_modifier extension for handling DRM format modifiers...
articles.title: NVK Vulkan Driver Lands DRM Format Modifiers Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Along with the IO_uring improvements for Linux 6.10, the block subsystem changes have also been merged for this new kernel version...
articles.title: Zone Write Plugging Comes To Linux 6.10 For Better Performance

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While much of the emphasis for Qualcomm's Snapdragon X Elite laptop SoC has been around Windows on Arm PCs, Qualcomm has also been working to have upstream Linux support for this high-end SoC and everything is coming together for said support...
articles.title: Qualcomm Talks Up Their Linux Support For The Snapdragon X Elite

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Raspberry Pi M.2 HAT+ has finally launched for allowing M.2 devices like NVMe drives, WiFi adapters, accelerators, and more to be connected to the Raspberry Pi 5...
articles.title: Raspberry Pi M.2 HAT+ Now Available For $12 To Connect NVMe Drives & More

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Manjaro 24.0 has been released today as the newest version of this Arch Linux derived desktop OS. Manjaro 24.0 ships with the latest the newly-released Linux 6.9 kernel and a slew of other updated packages...
articles.title: Manjaro 24.0 Released: Powered By Linux 6.9 & The Latest Desktops

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: There's another Rust upgrade coming for the Linux 6.10 kernel to bump the Rust version baseline required for building the Rust in-tree kernel components. This raising of the baseline will continue until a suitable minimum version is achieved where official Rust compiler "just works" well with the Rust'ed kernel bits. The Rust upgrade in Linux 6.10 also does away with its in-tree "alloc" fork for big code savings and simplifying maintenance...
articles.title: Rust 1.78 Upgrade For Linux 6.10, Dropping In-Tree "alloc" Fork To Save ~10k Lines

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The various ARM SoC/platform pull requests were already merged today by Linus Torvalds for the in-development Linux 6.10 kernel...
articles.title: More ARM-Based Handheld Game Consoles Supported By Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The work written about one month ago on Phoronix for much faster AES-XTS on modern Intel/AMD CPUs for speeding up disk and file encryption by as much as 155% with AMD Zen 4 CPUs has been submitted for Linux 6.10! As expected, this work providing new AES-XTS implementations for modern x86_64 processors is going into Linux 6.10 as part of the crypto subsystem updates...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Makes AES-XTS Disk/File Encryption Much Faster For Modern Intel/AMD CPUs

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While the Raspberry Pi 5 debuted last September already, sadly the mainline Linux kernel still lacks support for booting this popular single board computer... The support on Raspberry Pi OS and other downstream distributions/kernels is good, but the mainline kernel support for the Raspberry Pi SBCs remains a sore spot for this popular ARM single board computer. SUSE engineers have been working on implementing minimal boot support for the Raspberry Pi 5 that will hopefully make it to the mainline kernel...
articles.title: SUSE Working On Upstream Linux Kernel Support For Booting The Raspberry Pi 5

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Mozilla has pushed out its release images of the Firefox 126 web browser ahead of its official debut on Tuesday...
articles.title: Firefox 126 Available - Adds "Linux" To The Android User Agent String

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Back at Supercomputing 23, the Linux Foundation announced their intent on forming the High Performance Software Foundation for helping to advance open-source software for high performance computing (HPC). The Linux Foundation is now using ISC 24 this week in Hamburg, Germany for announcing that the High Performance Software Foundation has launched...
articles.title: Linux Foundation Launches The High Performance Software Foundation

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Today marks the first official day of the Linux 6.10 merge window. Among the horde of pull requests sent out today were the numerous x86 pull requests of material that's been queuing up in TIP.git of which there are many changes benefiting both Intel and AMD...
articles.title: x32 Shadow Stacks, Locking Optimizations, Intel VFM & Other x86 Changes For Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Building off last night's release of Linux 6.9 stable, GNU Linux-libre 6.9-gnu has debuted as this kernel downstream that works on stripping out support for any drivers/hardware depending upon closed-source firmware/microcode and other alterations in the name of software freedom...
articles.title: GNU Linux-libre 6.9 Released: More Deblobbing, Fixes Intel Graphics On GuC-Less Systems

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel, HPE, and Argonne National Laboratory have announced at ISC High Performance 2024 that the Aurora Supercomputer has broken the Excascale barrier and is now the fastest AI supercomputer currently in existence...
articles.title: Intel-Powered Aurora Supercomputer Breaks The Exascale Barrier

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Arch Linux derived CachyOS is known for its aggressive performance optimizations and running well on modern hardware. It's also leading when it comes to adopting other new Linux/open-source features. With this weekend's May 2024 ISO update, CachyOS has rolled out initial support for installing to a root file-system based on Bcachefs...
articles.title: Arch Linux Powered CachyOS Adds Bcachefs Installer Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Following last week's release of FreeBSD 14.1 Beta 1, this weekend brought the second beta candidate right on time...
articles.title: FreeBSD 14.1 Bringing Reproducibly Built Kernels, OpenZFS 2.2.4

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Linux 6.9 is out! Linux 6.9 has been released on time as the newest stable kernel version for rolling-release Linux distributions and other summer releases/updates. Linux 6.9 has a number of exciting features and improvements for those habitually updating to the newest version...
articles.title: Linux 6.9 Released With Faster Intel Core Ultra Performance, Larger Console Fonts Option

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Barring any last minute reservations by Linus Torvalds, Linux 6.9 stable should release later today. In turn the Linux 6.10 merge window will then open for the next two weeks and already some early pull requests have been submitted for this next kernel version. Here is a look at some of what to expect with the Linux 6.10 kernel...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Features Expected From The NTSYNC Driver To Performance Optimizations

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The recent AMD P-State Linux driver patches for heterogeneous core CPU topology, Fast CPPC, and Core Performance Boost haven't made it to the Linux power management's "-next" branch ahead of the imminent Linux 6.10 cycle. Thus it looks like those features won't be ready to make it for v6.10 unless by chance being deemed ready in the coming days and then sent in as part of a secondary set of merge window changes. However, some other AMD P-State fixes/improvements are queued up...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 AMD P-State To Deliver Fixes, Better Support On Older Zen CPUs

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: With the new Intel "Xe" Direct Rendering Manager kernel driver that's been in development one of the touted benefits of the clean sheet driver design is that it would enable using Intel discrete GPUs on non-x86 CPU architectures. The long-used "i915" DRM kernel graphics driver has many x86'isms in the code-base built up over the many years of Intel integrated graphics that were only ever found within their x86/x86_64 processors. But now in the era of Intel discrete graphics, there's been issues in trying to run Intel Arc Graphics on say ARM, POWER9, and RISC-V, among others. The experimental Intel Xe driver was recently successfully demonstrated in running on ARM using an Ampere Altra workstation...
articles.title: Intel Arc Graphics Demonstrated Running On ARM With Ampere Altra

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Following all of the GFX12 code and related IP landing within the AMDGPU Linux kernel driver as well as the LLVM AMDGPU shader compiler back-end and other code in enabling the next-generation of AMD Radeon graphics, the RadeonSI OpenGL driver support for RDNA4 (GFX12) was merged this Sunday into Mesa...
articles.title: AMD RDNA4 "GFX12" Support Merged For Mesa's RadeonSI Driver

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Linux I/O expert and subsystem maintainer Jens Axboe has submitted all of the IO_uring feature updates ahead of the imminent Linux 6.10 merge window...
articles.title: IO_uring Bringing Better Send Zero-Copy Performance With Linux 6.10

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Linux 6.9 kernel should debut as stable later today unless Linus Torvalds has second thoughts and decides to delay it by issuing a v6.9-rc8 kernel instead that would then push out the official release by an extra week. In any event, as a last-minute "x86/urgent" pull request is another Zen 5 PCI ID being added...
articles.title: Another AMD Zen 5 PCI ID Squeezing Into Linux 6.9

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The ReactOS project has posted their latest newsletter that outlines progress made during the past two months. ReactOS continues working to be an open-source operating system that offers application and driver binary compatibility with Microsoft Windows to in effect serve as a "open-source Windows" albeit the hardware support and application support are still an ongoing affair...
articles.title: ReactOS "Open-Source Windows" Making Good Strides On SMP CPU Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: For those interested in some insightful Linux kernel mailing list reading this weekend, there's been a vibrant discussion on the ability for the Linux kernel to mitigate unexpected arithmetic overflows/underflows/wraparounds...
articles.title: Torvalds Voices Thoughts On Linux Mitigating Unexpected Arithmetic Overflows/Underflows

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: KDE developer Xaver Hugl has written a third blog post outlining some of the latest HDR and color management improvements that have been readied for KDE's KWin compositor as well as ongoing improvements to Valve's Gamescope compositor...
articles.title: KDE Making Good Progress On HDR, Better Gamescope Integration

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Two years ago Cloudflare outlined how they began replacing Nginx with their own in-house creation, Pingora. Back in February of this year Cloudflare open-sourced Pingora and in April issued the maiden release of Pingora. Out today is Pingora 0.2 as the second release of this Rust framework that is already used in production by Cloudflare...
articles.title: Cloudflare Releases Pingora 0.2 For Building Fast & Reliable Networked Systems

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Rustls is the modern TLS library written in the Rust programming language with a large emphasis on memory safety and security. Rustls is backed by Google, AWS, and others as well as being a recipient of Germany's Sovereign Tech Fund. The latest exciting milestone for the open-source project is that Rustls can now work with Nginx...
articles.title: Rustls Can Now Work With Nginx Via New OpenSSL Compatibility Layer

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Wasmer 4.3 is out as the newest version of this WebAssembly (WASM) runtime that supports WASIX, WASI, and EmScript execution. This cross-platform WASM runtime continues to be focused on driving lightweight containers that can run anywhere in a very secure manner...
articles.title: Wasmer 4.3 Released: WebAssembly Runtime 25% Faster On Cold Startups

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: KDE developers had another busy week as more features were merged ahead of next month's Plasma 6.1 release...
articles.title: KDE Plasma 6 Sees More Features Merged Ahead Of Plasma 6.1

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While we are all waiting for the NVIDIA R555 series Linux driver beta that is expected to debut as soon as next week based on prior information with Wayland improvements (explicit sync) and more, with the NVIDIA R560 series Linux driver successor is a very interesting change: NVIDIA is planning on defaulting to using their open-source GPU kernel driver by default for GeForce RTX 2000 "Turing" GPUs and newer...
articles.title: NVIDIA's Open GPU Linux Kernel Driver Will Soon Be The Default For Turing & Newer GPUs

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: AMD last week sent out a set of patches to enhance the open-source FFmpeg multimedia library with integration around the AMD Advanced Media Framework (AMF). The AMF SDK allows for "optimal" access to AMD GPUs for multimedia processing but this patch series questioned the need in an era of Vulkan Video APIs beginning to see adoption...
articles.title: AMD Aims For AMF Decode In FFmpeg, Questioned Over Vulkan Video Commitment

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Linux 6.10 is introducing support for Trusted Platform Module (TPM2) encryption and integrity protections to prevent active/passive interposers from compromising them. This follows a recent security demonstration of TPM key recovery from Microsoft Windows BitLocker being demonstrated. TPM sniffing attacks have also been demonstrated against Linux systems too, thus the additional protections be made with Linux 6.10 to better secure TPM2 modules...
articles.title: Linux 6.10 Adding TPM Bus Encryption & Integrity Protection

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While Intel can be praised for their dozens (or likely by now, hundreds) of open-source projects they maintain and countless other existing open-source software projects they actively contribute to and are covered by Phoronix on a near-daily basis, not everything there is open-source. Intel is a wonderful and leading open-source promoter but occasionally there are closed-source blobs or questionable moves such as today: Intel is taking their Hyperscan library development from BSD-licensed open-source software to now the Intel Proprietary License moving forward...
articles.title: Intel Takes Open-Source Hyperscan Development To Proprietary Licensed Software

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Barring any last minute reservations by Linus Torvalds, the Linux 6.9 kernel should be released as stable on Sunday. It's been a fairly quiet week so Linux 6.9 stable will likely happen as opposed to going through an extra week with a 6.9-rc8 candidate. With this spring 2024 kernel there are many great features and improvements, especially for modern Intel and AMD platforms...
articles.title: Linux 6.9 Features Many Great Improvements For Both Intel & AMD

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: The Vulkan API 1.3.285 spec revision is out today with a handful of fixes/clarifications and another new extension developed by Valve engineering...
articles.title: Vulkan 1.3.285 Released With New Extension From Valve VKD3D-Proton Developer

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Building off last week's release of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.4 (RHEL 9.4) has been AlmaLinux 9.4 and now the other notable community-focused downstream: Rocky Linux 9.4...
articles.title: Rocky Linux 9.4 Released For RHEL 9.4 Derived Distribution

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Adding to the growing list of features coming with the SDL3 release for this hardware/software abstraction layer commonly used by cross-platform games and other software is PipeWire camera capturing support...
articles.title: SDL3 Adds PipeWire Camera Support

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Intel has released their Intel Extension for PyTorch v2.3 to succeed their earlier v2.1 derived extension. With this updated extension targeting PyTorch 2.3, Intel is rolling out more optimizations around Large Language Models (LLMs)...
articles.title: Intel Updates Its PyTorch Build With More Large Language Model Optimizations

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Valve tonight released a SteamOS 3.6 Preview as the latest version of their Arch Linux derived operating system that powers the Steam Deck and can be installed on other devices as well...
articles.title: SteamOS 3.6 Preview Released With Linux 6.5, Updated Arch Linux & Mesa 24.1

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: One of the interesting innovations out of Mozilla Ocho as the browser company's innovation and experiments group is Llamafile, a easy way to distribute and run AI large language models (LLMs) from a single file. Out this evening is Llamafile 0.8.2 is the newest release with an updated Llama.cpp and most excitingly are some AVX2 performance optimizations...
articles.title: Mozilla's Llamafile 0.8.2 Scores Big With New AVX2 Performance Optimizations

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Recently there was an LLVM bug report of "Worse runtime performance on Zen CPU when optimizing for Zen." Well, that's not good... Fortunately, that bug is now fixed with the latest LLVM Clang compiler code but other deficiencies in the AMD CPU optimization targeting remain...
articles.title: LLVM Dealing With Slower Performance On AMD CPUs When Targeting AMD Zen Optimizations

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: If all goes well the Linux 6.9 stable kernel will be released on Sunday and in turn mark the opening of the Linux 6.10 merge window. In hoping for an on-time release, some Linux kernel subsystem maintainers have been already submitting early pull requests of their feature material for v6.10. Among those early pulls are the SLAB (SLUB) updates...
articles.title: SLUB Updates Submitted Ahead Of Linux 6.10 Merge Window

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: A new patch series sent out today by AMD Linux engineers confirm that PCIe TPH will be supported with "upcoming AMD hardware" as a nice performance optimization feature for PCI Express...
articles.title: AMD Preparing PCIe TPH Support For Upcoming CPUs

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: While Canonical has been investing more into the performance of Ubuntu Linux and engaged some new performance improvements in Ubuntu 24.04 LTS, it's still not the fastest Linux distribution out there on x86_64 hardware. Similarly, the recently released Fedora Workstation 40 features the brand new GCC 14 compiler and other leading-edge open-source software packages, but there's still more performance left on the table as shown by Intel. Here are some fresh benchmarks looking at how Ubuntu 24.04 LTS and Fedora Workstation 40 are competing with Intel's in-house Clear Linux distribution that offers aggressive x86_64 Linux performance defaults and the best possible out-of-the-box Linux performance on modern x86_64 hardware.
articles.title: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS & Fedora 40 Continue To Trail Intel's Linux Performance Optimizations

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: As expected, AMD today published the Micro Engine Scheduler "MES" firmware documentation for RDNA3 graphics processors as part of better engaging with the open-source community and aiming to address some gaps in their open-source GPU compute stack...
articles.title: AMD Publishes Micro Engine Scheduler "MES" Firmware Documentation

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: In addition to a Framework Laptop EC driver being prepared for Linux that extends the Chrome OS embedded controller (EC) used by recent Framework Laptops, a ChromeOS EC hardware monitoring (HWMON subsystem) driver has also been revived as a further support extension for Framework laptops on Linux...
articles.title: ChromeOS EC Hardware Monitoring Driver Being Revived For Framework Laptops

articles.author: Michael Larabel
articles.description: Recently I've been testing out the Scaleway's Elastic Metal RV1 (EM-RV1) RISC-V cloud servers. Initially they were using Ubuntu 23.10 for providing an up-to-date Ubuntu Linux RISC-V experience while quickly upgraded to Ubuntu 24.04 LTS. For those curious how Ubuntu 24.04 is performing on RISC-V hardware, here are some comparison benchmarks.
articles.title: RISC-V Performance On Ubuntu 24.04 LTS With Scaleway's EM-RV1
